questions.text: Most definitive test to prove monozygosity in twins:
questions.solution:
This is the most definitive test for proving monozygosity. The DNA microprobe technique involves comparing the twins' genetic material at a very detailed level. Monozygotic twins will have identical DNA sequences, while dizygotic twins will not. This test is accurate and non-invasive, making it the gold standard for determining monozygosity.

Most definitive test to prove monozygosity in twins:

OPTION a. Same gender:
Twins of the same gender could either be monozygotic (identical) or dizygotic (fraternal). While all monozygotic twins are of the same gender, dizygotic twins can also share the same gender. Hence, this is not a definitive test to prove monozygosity.

OPTION b. Same blood group:
Although monozygotic twins generally have the same blood group, dizygotic twins can also occasionally share the same blood group. Therefore, this is not a conclusive test for proving monozygosity.

OPTION c. Test skin graft:
Skin grafting between monozygotic twins tends to be accepted because their tissues are genetically identical. However, this method is invasive and not commonly used in modern practice to determine zygosity. It is not considered definitive due to ethical and practical concerns.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

Monozygotic twins

  • Sex: While twins having opposite sex are almost always dizygotic and twins of the same sex are not always monozygotic but the uniovular twins are always of the same sex. If the fetuses are of the same sex and have the same genetic features (dominant blood group), monozygosity is likely.
  • A test skin graft-Acceptance of reciprocal skin graft is almost a certain proof of monozygosity.
  • DNA microprobe technique is most definitive
  • Follow-up study between 2 and 4 years-showing almost similar physical and behavioural features suggestive of monozygosity.

questions.text: With spontaneous conception, maximum incidence of dizygotic twin gestation is seen at what maternal age?
questions.solution:
• Increased incidence of twinning is observed with the advancing age of the mother, the maximum being between the age of 30 and 35 years. The incidence of twins is markedly reduced thereafter.
  • Higher levels of FSH have been linked with dizygotic twinning.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

For the fetus, maternal age-related complications(age>35yr) primarily originate from:

  1. Indicated preterm delivery or maternal complications such as hypertension and diabetes,
  2. Spontaneous preterm birth,
  3. Fetal-growth disorders related to chronic maternal disease or multifetal gestation,
  4. Fetal aneuploidy,
  5. Pregnancies resulting from assisted reproductive techniqe

questions.text: Most common type of conjoint twins:
questions.solution:
Thoracopagus (joined at the thorax) is the most common variant of conjoint twins.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

  • The frequency of conjoined twins has a prevalence of 1.5 in 100,000 births, and thoracopagus is the most common type.
  • During sonographic interrogation, fetal poles are seen to be closely associated and do not change relative position from one another
  • Other clues are more than three vessels in the umbilical cord, fewer limbs than expected, spine hyperflexion, big fetal pole, and increased nuchal thickness.

questions.text: A 28 year old Gravida 3 Abortion 2 with 38 weeks of gestation was admitted to labour room with complaints of pain in lower abdomen since morning. Her first trimester was uneventful and was diagnosed with monochorionic diamniotic twin gestation at 11th week. At 26 weeks of gestation, her USG report showed one live and active fetus of 26 weeks 2 days and other was dead. Patient's attendants were counselled regarding the condition and risks upon continuation of pregnancy to the mother and fetus were explained. Conservative management was done with sonography every three weeks and coagulation profile every fortnight. At the time of admission, General Physical examination was normal. Obstetric examination revealed fundal height corresponding to term gestation, single fetus with cephalic presentation with FHR 148 bpm. Per vaginal examination showed cervical dilation of 2 cm. USG done showed oligohydraminos (AFI=3). Emergency caeserean section was performed; a live term IUGR female baby of 2.2kg was delivered. On careful examination of placenta, two cords were noticed and it was identified as diamniotic monochorionic placenta with the following finding (as shown in the image), Identify this condition:
questions.solution:
Fetus papyraceus is a rare condition where a fetus dies in the womb early in pregnancy and becomes compressed between the uterine wall and the membranes. The dead fetus mummifies and takes on a parchment-like appearance. It's usually diagnosed during labor or after delivery.


a. TRAP syndrome (Twin Reversed Arterial Perfusion syndrome):

TRAP syndrome is a rare complication of monochorionic twin pregnancies where one twin (the "acardiac twin") develops without a heart and other critical structures, while the other twin (the "pump twin") provides blood to both fetuses. The pump twin is at risk of heart failure due to the increased cardiovascular load. The acardiac twin usually has severe malformations and is non-viable.

b. TTTS (Twin-to-Twin Transfusion Syndrome):

TTTS occurs in monochorionic twin pregnancies where the twins share a single placenta. Due to abnormal vascular connections within the placenta, blood flows disproportionately between the twins, causing one twin (the donor) to have reduced blood volume and amniotic fluid, while the other twin (the recipient) receives excess blood, which can lead to heart problems and polyhydramnios. Without treatment, TTTS can result in serious complications for both twins.

d. Fetus in fetu:

Fetus in fetu is a rare condition in which a malformed fetus is found inside the body of its twin. This abnormality occurs during early embryonic development, when one twin becomes trapped within the other. The "fetus" in this case is not viable and is often detected as a mass in the body of the surviving twin. Surgical removal is generally required, but it is a benign condition.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

Fetus papyraceus refers to the condition where one twin in a multiple pregnancy dies in utero early in the pregnancy and is compressed by the growth of the surviving twin, becoming flattened and mummified. This condition is typically discovered during delivery or through ultrasound. It usually occurs in the second or third trimester.

questions.text: Most common presentation of fetuses in a twin gestation:
questions.solution:
LIE AND PRESENTATION IN TWIN GESTATION

The most common lie of the fetuses is longitudinal (90%) but malpresentations are quite common.

The combination of presentation of the fetuses are:

  1. Both vertex (50%)
  2. First vertex and second breech (30%)
  3. First breech and second vertex (10%)
  4. Both breech (10%)
  5. First vertex and second transverse and so on.

But rarest one, being both transverse when the possibility of conjoined twins should be ruled out.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

  • Both vertex is most common presentation in twin pregnancy.
  • Vaginal delivery can be done in this scenario.
  • LSCS is to be done if first baby is breech irrespective of 2nd twin.

questions.text: A 32 year old primigravida conceived with IVF is diagnosed with twin gestation. She undergoes a scan at 11 weeks of gestation for determination of chorionicity. The following is seen. What is the type of twin gestation in this pregnancy?
questions.solution:
• Early diagnosis and determination of chorionicity in the first trimester are critical for the optimal management of multiple gestations.
  • Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation.
  • In dichorionic twins there is a thick septum between the two gestational sacs. It is best identified at the base of the membrane, where a triangular projection is seen. This is known as lambda or twin peak sign.
  • Presence of lambda or twin peak sign indicates dichorionic placenta.

LAMBDA SIGN(Dichorionic diamniotic) T sign(Monochorionic diamniotic)

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

  • Lambda sign on USG suggests DCDA twins.
  • T sign suggests MCDA twins.

Mechanism of monozygotic twinning:-

choices.text: The recipient twin becomes larger with hydramnios, polycythemic, hypertensive & hypervolemic
The donor twin becomes smaller with oligohydramnios, anaemic, hypotensive and hypovolemic
The recipient twin has a better clinical outcome
Laser photocoagulation to interrupt the anastomotic vessels can be done

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding Twin-to-Twin Transfusion Syndrome, except:
questions.solution:
Although the recipient twin appears larger and may seem healthier initially, it is at a high risk for complications such as heart failure, hydrops fetalis, and other cardiovascular issues. Option-wise explanations:

  • In TTTS, the recipient twin receives an excess of blood, leading to hypervolemia, polycythemia, and increased amniotic fluid (hydramnios). This twin is at risk for cardiac complications due to fluid overload.
  • The donor twin suffers from a lack of blood supply, resulting in anemia, hypovolemia, hypotension, and decreased amniotic fluid (oligohydramnios), which is characteristic of the "stuck twin" phenomenon.
  • Laser photocoagulation is a definitive treatment option for TTTS. It involves the ablation of the shared placental vessels to stop the abnormal blood flow between the twins, improving survival chances for both twins.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

Both twins in TTTS are at risk of various complications no one has better outcome.

choices.text: The incidence is same across all variants

questions.text: The following complication is most commonly seen with which variant of twin gestation?
questions.solution:
The above image depicts CORD ENTANGLEMENT.

  • Dichorionic Diamniotic:
    In this type of twin gestation, each twin has its own placenta and amniotic sac, which reduces the likelihood of cord entanglement because the cords are less likely to cross.
  • Monochorionic Diamniotic:
    While these twins share a placenta, they have separate amniotic sacs. This setup allows for some movement but does not create a high risk of cord entanglement compared to monoamniotic twins.
  • The incidence is same across all variants:
    This statement is incorrect, as the incidence of cord entanglement varies significantly with the type of twin gestation.

Therefore, cord entanglement is most commonly seen in monochorionic monoamniotic twins due to their shared environment.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

  • In MCMA type of twin gestation, both twins share a single amniotic sac. The close proximity and freedom of movement within the sac significantly increase the risk of cord entanglement, which can lead to complications such as cord compression and fetal distress.
  • If fetal testing remains reassuring and no other intervening indications arise, cesarean delivery is performed at 320/7 to 340/7 weeks’ gestation in MCMA
  • Optimum time for delivery of twins:

Dichorionic diamniotic: 38w

Monochorionic monoamniotic: 34-37w

Monochorionic monoamniotic: 32-34w

choices.text: Decision based on gestational age, cause of death & risk to the surviving twin
Vanishing twin will not affect the surviving twin
In death after 1st trimester, risk of preterm birth increases in both monochorionic & dichorionic twins
Neurological prognosis for the surviving twin does not depend on chorionicity

questions.text: In death of one fetus in a twin gestation, that is a case of single fetal demise, all are true except:
questions.solution:
The neurological prognosis for the surviving twin can be influenced by chorionicity. Monochorionic twins are at a higher risk for complications such as TTTS and other vascular-related issues that can affect the neurological outcomes of the surviving twin.

Option a. Decision based on gestational age, cause of death & risk to the surviving twin:
Correct. Management decisions following the death of one twin consider factors such as gestational age, the cause of death, and the potential risks to the surviving twin.

Option b. In many cases, a vanishing twin (a twin that is lost early in pregnancy) typically has little to no impact on the surviving twin's health, especially if it occurs early in the first trimester.

Option c. The risk of preterm birth increases after the death of one twin, regardless of chorionicity, particularly if the demise occurs later in the pregnancy.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

  • Monochorionic twins are at a higher risk for complications such as TTTS and other vascular-related issues that can affect the neurological outcomes of the surviving twin.

questions.text: A 34 year old G3P0A2 woman undertakes In Vitro Fertilization after 6 years of her last fetal loss. She conceives a quadruplet pregnancy which was diagnosed sonographically at 10 weeks of gestation. The pros & cons of multifetal pregnancy reduction were then discussed with the couple. They opted for the procedure, where some drug was used to induce cardiac asystole in the extra fetuses, thus making the pregnancy safer. Which of the following could be the drug used for multifetal pregnancy reduction?
questions.solution:
Doxorubicin:
This is a chemotherapeutic agent used primarily in cancer treatment. It is not used for multifetal pregnancy reduction due to its toxic effects and lack of specific action in this context.

Colchicine:
Colchicine is used to treat gout and certain other conditions but is not suitable for inducing cardiac asystole in fetuses.

KCl (Potassium Chloride):
Correct. KCl is commonly used in multifetal pregnancy reduction procedures. It induces cardiac asystole in the targeted fetuses when injected, making the procedure effective and safer for the remaining fetus(es).

Ethacridine lactate:
Ethacridine lactate has been used for medical abortion in certain cases but is not the standard drug used for multifetal pregnancy reduction.

In summary, KCl is the drug used to induce cardiac asystole in the extra fetuses during multifetal pregnancy reduction.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

  • For reductions of fetuses with their own chorion, potassium chloride is used and is injected into the fetal heart or thorax.
  • Entering or traversing the sacs of fetuses picked or retention is avoided.
  • For monochorionic fetuses and potentially shared vasculature, cord-occlusion is used, and with radiofrequency ablation (RFA), the needle is inserted into the intrafetal portion of the umbilical cord.

choices.text: Weekly CTG & USG monitoring uptill 37 weeks
Perform A Caesarean section at 37 weeks of gestation
Perform a Caesarean section after administering a course of corticosteroids

questions.text: A G2P1L1 woman, prior full term vaginal delivery, is bearing a monochorionic monoamniotic twin gestation. She visits to you at 33 weeks of gestation. She has no other pregnancy complications. What should be the ideal management of this case?
questions.solution:
• The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists recommends delivery at 380/7 to 386/7 weeks' gestation for uncomplicated dichorionic diamnionic twin pregnancies.
  • Uncomplicated monochorionic diamniotic twin pregnancies can be delivered between 340/7 and 376/7
  • For monochorionic monoamniotic twin pregnancies, delivery is recommended at 320/7 to 340/7 weeks
  • Since gestation is <34 weeks, it is ideal to give a course of antenatal corticosteroids to aim at a better fetal outcome.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

  • If MCMA fetal testing remains reassuring and no other intervening indications arise, cesarean delivery is performed at 320/7 to 340/7 weeks' gestation.
  • MCDA between 340/7 and 376/7
  • DCDA at 380/7 to 386/7 weeks' gestation

choices.text: Repeat umbilical artery Doppler in 1 week
Urgent referral for laser ablation of vascular anastomoses in the placental bed

questions.text:
A primigravida presents at the antenatal clinic with a monochorionic diamniotic twin pregnancy at 24 weeks of gestation. In a Doppler USG, Twin 1 showed oligohydramnios (AFI = 3 cm) with absent end diastolic flow in the umbilical artery. Twin 2 showed polyhydramnios (AFI = 28 cm) with good end diastolic flow in the umbilical artery Doppler.
What would be the best line of management in this scenario?
questions.solution:
• Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS) occurs if there is shift in the net blood flow between the two fetuses resulting in hypervolemia in one fetus and hypovolemia in the other fetus, this shift is caused by the architecture of the vessels on the surface of the placenta.
  • The donor is characterized by hypovolemia and oligo-/anhydramnios. This is often associated with an empty bladder, growth restriction and abnormal Doppler flow in the umbilical artery.
  • Quintero staging is useful for prognosis & guides the management.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

Quintero staging is used prognosis and management of TTTS:-

  • Stage I: Expectant management is recommended due to outcomes similar to amnioreduction and fetoscopic laser photocoagulation. Weekly ultrasound checks can be considered.
  • Stage II, III, IV: Fetoscopic laser photocoagulation is recommended at these stages at gestational age < 26 weeks.
  • The given presentation is of Quintero stage III and gestational age is <26 weeks, so laser ablation of placental vascular anastomoses is the best option.

questions.text: If a zygote divides within first 72 hours after fertilization, which of the following type of twin gestation results?
questions.solution:
• The outcome of the monozygotic twinning process depends on when division occurs.
  • If zygotes divide within the first 72 hours after fertilization, two embryos, two amnions, and two chorions develop, and a monozygotic, dichorionic, diamnionic twin gestation evolves. Two distinct placentas or a single, fused placenta may develop.
  • If division occurs between days 4 to 8, a monozygotic, monochorionic, diamnionic twin pregnancy results.
  • By 8 days, the chorion and the amnion have already differentiated, and division results in two embryos within a common amnionic sac, which is a monozygotic, monochorionic, monoamnionic twin gestation.
  • Conjoined twins result if division initiates later >14 days

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

Mechanism of monozygotic twinning:-

questions.text: Which of the following fetal vessels is key to monitoring of TAPS (Twin Anaemia Polycythaemia Sequence)?
questions.solution:
Middle cerebral artery (MCA) is crucial in monitoring TAPS because it helps assess the blood flow and the presence of anemia in the donor twin. An increase in peak systolic velocity in the MCA indicates the presence of anemia in the donor twin due to TAPS.

a. Umbilical artery:

Monitoring the umbilical artery primarily provides information about the blood flow to the fetus but is not specifically key for diagnosing or monitoring TAPS.

c. Ductus venosus:

The ductus venosus is involved in assessing fetal hemodynamics but is not specifically used for monitoring TAPS.

d. Umbilical vein:

While the umbilical vein carries oxygenated blood to the fetus, it is not the primary vessel monitored in the context of TAPS.

In summary, the middle cerebral artery is key to monitoring TAPS as it provides critical information about the hemodynamic status of the affected twins

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

  • Twin Anaemia Polycythaemia Sequence (TAPS) is an imbalance in hemoglobin without a volume distribution disparity in monochorionic twins.
  • It is most commonly seen after fetoscopic laser coagulation for TTTS, but may also arise spontaneously.
  • Routine monitoring of the MCA peak systolic velocity (PSV) from 20 weeks onwards in order to detect TAPS, allows decisions to be made about management in a timely fashion.

questions.text: The interval between delivery of twin one and twin two should generally be less than:
questions.solution:
• Delivery of twin two should not be rushed if there is no cord prolapse or bleeding, and if the fetal heart rate remains normal.
  • The interval between delivery of twin one and twin two should generally be less than 30 minutes, but may be prolonged if the fetal heart rate is normal.
  • A prolonged interval can increase the risk of complications, such as uterine atony, hemorrhage, and increased morbidity for the second twin.
  • While some sources may specify different timeframes, 30 minutes is a commonly accepted guideline in obstetric practice for the safe delivery of twins.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

The interval between delivery of twin one and twin two should generally be less than 30 minutes, but may be prolonged if the fetal heart rate is normal.

questions.text: Most accurate method to establish or confirm gestational age:
questions.solution:
• Ultrasound measurement of the crown-rump length (CRL) is the most accurate method to establish or confirm gestational age.
  • Transvaginal imaging yields higher resolution images.
  • Before 14 weeks' gestation, the CRL is accurate to within 5 to 7 days.
  • Starting at 14 weeks’ gestation, the biparietal diameter, head circumference, abdominal circumference, and femur length should be measured.
  • Before 22 weeks, gestational age assessment using these four biometric parameters is accurate to within 7 to 10 days.

Optionwise explanation:

  • BPD in 2nd trimester: While Biparietal Diameter (BPD) is a common measurement used in the second trimester, it is less accurate than CRL because fetal proportions can vary more significantly in this period.
  • HC in 2nd trimester: Head Circumference (HC) is another important measurement but, like BPD, is also subject to variability in fetal growth patterns, making it less reliable than CRL.
  • FL in 3rd trimester: Femur Length (FL) is used in the third trimester but is not as accurate for dating as CRL, especially since fetal growth can vary widely at this stage.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

choices.text: Gastroschisis is not covered by a membrane
Omphalocoele is usually associated with a chromosomal anomaly in 40-60% of cases
Intestinal atresia is rare in an omphalocoele

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding gastroschisis & omphalocoele?
questions.solution:
Omphalocoele is actually a central defect at the umbilical site, where the abdominal contents are herniated into a sac, whereas gastroschisis is a defect to the side of the umbilicus.

Optionwise Explanation:

  • Gastroschisis is not covered by a membrane: This statement is true. In gastroschisis, the intestines are exposed and not covered by a protective membrane.
  • Omphalocoele is usually associated with a chromosomal anomaly in 40–60% of cases: This statement is true. Omphalocoele is often associated with chromosomal abnormalities, such as trisomies.
  • Intestinal atresia is rare in an omphalocoele: This statement is true. Unlike gastroschisis, where intestinal atresia is more common, it is rare in omphalocoele cases.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

choices.text: The most common site of herniation is through the posterolateral defect (foramen of Bochdalek) in the pleuro-peritoneal canal
Left-sided hernias are more common than right-sided hernias
Antenatally the condition can present with oligohydramnios
This may lead to the underdevelopment of lungs and pulmonary hypoplasia, which is often lethal

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about congenital diaphragmatic hernia?
questions.solution:
Antenatally, Congenital diaphragmatic Hernia can present with polyhydramnios, and not oligohydramnios. Polyhydramnios is common, either due to esophageal compression or reduced absorption of fluid by the hypoplastic lungs, but it is rarely observed before 24 week gestation.

Optionwise Explanation:

a. The most common site of herniation is through the posterolateral defect (foramen of Bochdalek) in the pleuro-peritoneal canal: This statement is true. The foramen of Bochdalek is indeed the most common site for CDH, usually located on the left side.

b. Left-sided hernias are more common than right-sided hernias: This statement is true. Left-sided CDH is more prevalent, occurring in about 70-90% of cases.

d. This may lead to the underdevelopment of lungs and pulmonary hypoplasia, which is often lethal: This statement is true. The presence of herniated abdominal contents in the thorax can cause lung hypoplasia, which is a significant complication and can lead to mortality.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

"Tips & Tricks"

To remember the side in which a Bochdalek hernia more commonly occurs (and to contrast with Morgagni hernias) Bochdalek has an L for left and Morgagni has an R for right.

questions.text: A 24 year old primigravida attends her 1st OB visit at 6 weeks of gestation. The obstetrician tells her that a scan would be done to measure the Nuchal Translucency at a specified gestational age. What is the ideal time for an NT scan?
questions.solution:
NT is the sonographic appearance of a subcutaneous collection of fluid behind the fetal neck in the first trimester of pregnancy, which is best performed at 11-14 weeks gestation.This timing allows for accurate measurement of the nuchal translucency, which is an important marker for assessing the risk of chromosomal abnormalities such as Down syndrome.

Option-wise Explanation:

a. 6 to 8+6 weeks

  • This time frame is too early for a reliable NT measurement, as the nuchal translucency is not well-developed at this stage.

b. 9 to 10+6 weeks

  • This period is also too early for accurate NT measurement, and the results may not be reliable.

d. 14 to 17+6 weeks

  • While scans can be performed during this time for other assessments, the NT measurement is not typically done after 13+6 weeks, as the nuchal translucency is no longer a reliable indicator for screening.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

First-trimester Aneuploidy Screening

  • This test includes HCG ,PAPP-A, and ultra-sound measurement of the nuchal translucency .
  • It is performed between 11 and 14 weeks’ gestation.
  • Pregnancies with fetal trisomy 21 are characterized by higher levels of hCG and lower PAPP-A. With trisomy 18 and trisomy 13, levels of both analytes are lower

questions.text: A 34 year old G2P0A1 is subjected to first trimester screening. All of the following are components of 1st trimester screening, except:
questions.solution:
Option-wise Explanation:

a. Maternal age

  • Maternal age is a critical component of first trimester screening as it helps assess the risk for chromosomal abnormalities like Down syndrome.

b. Nuchal translucency

  • Nuchal translucency measurement via ultrasound is a key component of first trimester screening. It assesses the fluid collection at the back of the fetus's neck, which can indicate chromosomal abnormalities.

c. Maternal serum beta-hCG level

  • The measurement of maternal serum beta-hCG (human chorionic gonadotropin) is included in first trimester screening. Abnormal levels can indicate increased risk for certain conditions.

d. Maternal serum unconjugated estriol 3 level

  • Maternal serum unconjugated estriol is not typically measured during first trimester screening. It is part of the second trimester screening (quad screen), which assesses multiple markers for fetal health and chromosomal abnormalities.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

questions.text: The risk of all of the following increases with advancing maternal age, except:
questions.solution:
• Advanced maternal age increases the likelihood of having a pregnancy affected by a chromosomal abnormality.
  • The risk of trisomies 13, 18 and 21 all increase with advancing maternal age.
  • However, the risk of Turner syndrome is not altered with maternal age.

Option-wise Explanation:

a. Down’s syndrome (Trisomy 21)

  • The risk of Down's syndrome significantly increases with advancing maternal age, particularly after age 35. This is due to the age-related decline in oocyte quality and the risk of nondisjunction during meiosis.

b. Patau syndrome (Trisomy 13)

  • Similar to Down's syndrome, the risk of Patau syndrome also increases with maternal age. The incidence of this chromosomal abnormality rises with the age of the mother.

c. Edward syndrome (Trisomy 18)

  • The risk of Edward syndrome is higher in older mothers as well. Like other trisomies, it is associated with increased maternal age.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

  • Turner syndrome typically results from a random error during the formation of reproductive cells, rather than maternal age-related factors. The incidence of Turner syndrome occurs equally across maternal age groups.

questions.text: Amniocentesis should not be performed prior to ___ weeks of gestation:
questions.solution:
• There is good evidence that amniocentesis should not be performed before 15+0 weeks' gestation owing to the higher risk of pregnancy loss and the potential for talipes equinovarus.
  • Early amniocentesis also resulted in an increase in requirement for multiple needle insertions
  • Early amniocentesis has cytogenetic implications, with increased risk of failed culture of compared with mid-trimester amniocentesis and potential for false negative results.

Risks and Benefits

  • Benefits:
    • Early detection of genetic conditions.
    • Allows for informed decision-making regarding pregnancy management.
  • Risks:
    • Miscarriage (about 1 in 300 to 1 in 500).
    • Infection.
    • Injury to the fetus or placenta.
    • Leakage of amniotic fluid.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

  • Ideal Timing: Amniocentesis is typically performed between 15+0 weeks and 20+0 weeks of gestation.
  • Minimum Gestational Age:
    • Before 15 weeks: Amniocentesis should not be performed prior to 15 weeks of gestation because:
      • There is a higher risk of miscarriage and complications if performed earlier.
      • The amount of amniotic fluid available for sampling is often insufficient before this time.

Reference: RCOG Green Top Guideline No. 8, Amniocentesis & Chorionic villus sampling

questions.text: Chorionic villus sampling should not be performed prior to ___ weeks of gestation:
questions.solution:
• CVS should not be performed before 10+0 weeks' gestation
  • With CVS before 10+0 weeks' gestation there is a possible association with oromandibular and limb defects.

Timing of CVS

  • Ideal Timing: CVS is ideally performed between 10+0 weeks and 13+6 weeks of gestation.
  • Minimum Gestational Age:
    • Before 10 weeks: Performing CVS before 10 weeks is associated with an increased risk of complications .
    • Risks and Benefits
  • Benefits:
    • Early detection of genetic conditions.
    • Allows for informed decision-making regarding pregnancy management.
  • Risks:
    • Miscarriage (1-2% risk).
    • Injury to the fetus or placenta.
    • Limb defects if performed before 10 weeks.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

  • The problem with CVS was its association with limb-reduction defects and oromandibular limb hypogenesis when performed at 7 weeks of gestation
  • When perormed at or after 10 weeks' gestation, the incidence of limb defects does not exceed the background population rate

Reference: RCOG Green Top Guideline No. 8, Amniocentesis & Chorionic villus sampling

questions.text: The highest chance of fetal loss is associated with which prenatal testing modality?
questions.solution:
Cordocentesis because it has the highest chance of fetal loss compared to other prenatal testing modalities.

  • a. Amniocentesis
    • Procedure: Involves extracting amniotic fluid using a needle inserted through the abdominal wall.
    • Risk of Fetal Loss: Approximately 1 in 300 to 1 in 500 pregnancies.
  • b. Chorionic villus sampling (CVS)
    • Procedure: Involves sampling chorionic villi from the placenta, either transcervically or transabdominally.
    • Risk of Fetal Loss: Approximately 1 in 100 to 1 in 200 pregnancies.
  • c. Cordocentesis (Percutaneous Umbilical Blood Sampling)
    • Procedure: Involves obtaining a blood sample from the fetal umbilical cord.
    • Risk of Fetal Loss: Approximately 1 in 30 to 1 in 50 pregnancies.
  • d. Cell-free fetal DNA test
    • Procedure: Involves analyzing fragments of fetal DNA found in the mother's blood.
    • Risk of Fetal Loss: No associated risk of miscarriage, as it is a non-invasive test.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

Reference: Amniocentesis and chorionic villus sampling for prenatal diagnosis. Alfirevic Z, Navaratnam K, Mujezinovic F. Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2017;9:0.

questions.text: TIFFA scan is performed at what gestational age?
questions.solution:
Targeted Imaging for Fetal Anomalies (TIFFA), Fetal Anomaly Scan, or ultrasound level II scan is another term for the anomaly scan.

Though this TIFFA ultrasound scan can be performed anytime between 18 and 22 weeks of pregnancy, it is ideally performed between 18 and 20 weeks after conception.

Optionwise Explanation

  • a. 6-9 weeks
    • Details: This period is typically used for early ultrasounds, such as confirming pregnancy and assessing fetal viability.
  • b. 11-14 weeks
    • Details: This timeframe is generally used for first-trimester screening, including nuchal translucency measurements.
  • d. 28-32 weeks
    • Details: This period is used for growth scans and assessing fetal well-being rather than a comprehensive anatomical assessment.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

TIFFA is done at 18-22 weeks because this is the gestational age range to assess fetal anatomy and detect potential anomalies.

Reference: Second trimester ultrasound scan. Reference article, Radiopaedia.org https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-15626

questions.text: Which chromosomal anomaly is commonly associated with the following imaging pattern?
questions.solution:
Double bubble sign suggests duodenal atresia.

  • The fetal abdomen shows dilated stomach and the first part of the duodenum, suspicious for duodenal atresia.
  • In cross-section, giving the appearance of a double bubble sign.
  • About 30% of children with duodenal atresia can have Down Syndrome.
  • Associated Anomalies: Besides duodenal atresia, Down's syndrome may be associated with other gastrointestinal anomalies, such as esophageal atresia and malrotation, as well as congenital heart defects.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

  • The most prevalent anomalies in affected children are cardiac and gasrointestinal.
  • Cardiac abnormalities particularly endocardial cushion defects and ventricular septal defect
  • Gastro-intestinal abnormalities are identified in 6 to 12 percent and include esophageal atresia,duodenal atresia, and Hirschsprung Disease.
  • Males with Down syndrome have markedly reduced spermatogenesis and are almost always sterile.
  • The average intelligence quotient (IQ)score is 35 to 70.
  • Typical findings include brachycephaly; epicanthal folds and up-slanting palpebral fissures; Brushfield spots which are whitish spots on the periphery of the iris; a flat nasal bridge; and hypotonia
  • "Sandal-gap" between the first and second toes, short fingers, a single palmar crease and clinodactyly of the fifth digit
